review_text: I have to say I wanted to love this product as I have loved all apple products, and when it came out of the box I did. The issues only started when I used it for what it was designed for - to stream content. The most important problem with the Apple TV is the fact that it does not reliably play streaming content and often goes into a death spiral “spin”. You know what I mean about that wheel of death. Even when it does not freeze and try to reload altogether, it frequently just stops producing audio or gets stuck on the video even though the audio keeps going. I have almost a gig of reliable download speed from Xfinity, so my bandwidth is not the problem. I was so frustrated tonight that I disconnected the thing - no easy feat because it is wired into the home theater and connect my Fire Cube from another room - bang, back in business and no issue whatsoever. So if it is not the network and another streaming platform has no issue, then it has to be the Apple TV. I thought I was just going to have to eat the cost and go buy another Fire TV, but I was super happy to find I could still return it. One other negative is the remote. It looks SOOOO beautiful, but whoever thought a fragile glass TV remote was a good idea lived in a china shop with no people. Remotes get dropped, they fall through cushions and end up on the floor. Less than 2 days after having it, there was a ship in the glass. On top of that, the remote does not respond to the touch pad swipes. You are swiping and swiping - it does not repond and then suddenly it does and you are five icons over from where you were trying to get only to repeat the whole cycle again. Yes the Fire TV and Roku (I have both in different rooms) are a bit slower with the mechanical button, but at least they respond when you push them. One upside I liked and which sold me to try it when I had such good experience with Fire TV was the year free Apple +. We watched a few things and the content was excellent, but if I want that I can just pay for it on the app I download on Fire TV and not have to deal with the frustration of the streaming freezing all the time.

I don't think it's any worse than dropping my universal remote or hitting a wrong button on another remote. My only complaints about the Apple TV remote is that there is no mute button and it is quite small, so don't misplace it!UI - I'm not very familiar with the iOS environment. I have an iPhone but have only had it a couple of years so I'm still behind the function curve. Overall the system was mostly intuitive but I did make sure to familiarize myself with some online hints and tricks before it arrived so I knew how to navigate.App and menu interface - Someone mentioned in a review that all app menus were universally similar on the Apple TV. I found this to not be the case. As with any other device, Hulu, Netflix, Amazon and HBO all have their unique functionality.Up Next Feature - does not really work as advertised. I find it to be intermittent. Not all shows update like it said they would and not all appear on the home screen. Netflix specifically doesn't seem to play well with this feature, but overall each of the apps has failed to display the next episode of a show I have watched on the device.Quality and functionality - Quality and functionality is awesome. Content looks great and I have had few issues. Make sure you have an HDMI cable rated for 4k content or you will receive a warning (evidently I had an older one connected). The Apple TV connects easily to my iPhone for typing, filling in account fields and setting up. You can also download the Remote app from iTunes (to your phone) in order to use your phone as a remote, but I don't actually find this very convenient or helpful as I am perfectly happy with the remote.Biggest Con - Users of Bose Cinemate 130 beware. Evidently this system will not work with the Apple TV 4k. While I am able to connect sound from my Apple TV to the Bose system via direct input into the TV, I was not able to connect through the Bose Receiver. This is apparently a known issue to Bose, but they have no intention of fixing the issue leaving those of us that spent a significant amount of money to fend for ourselves. This was nearly devastating when I was trying to setup but thankfully I found a forum that directed me to a workaround.Summary - Overall I am quite happy with my purchase. I'm hoping after more updates the up next field is more accurate as it is pretty great to not need to jump into individual apps when your watching a series. I am also hopeful that eventually Spotify will be available via the Apple TV, but so far it isn't an option for download. Otherwise this is a great device that's easy to use and so much more reliable than the apps loaded into my Samsung Smart TV. Oh, and almost forgot to mention the screensaver. The photos (especially the aerial images) really are mesmerizing as another reviewer mentioned. My friends almost always comment about the cool images on the TV when they walk in, so just a minor added bonus if you needed one .

review_title: So much better than the previous versions
review_text: So much better than the previous versions. Streaming 4K HDR works far better than through my Sony 930e with no delay or audio problems, which were extremely frustrating. I have noticed a number of people posting issues with making the HDR connection. Apple TV does this during the set up, and it didn't work at first. There are three things (at least) that you might want to check if you cannot establish the 4K HDR connection. First, make sure your HDMI cables are high speed cables. Second, if you are connecting directly from Apple TV to your TV and not through your receiver, make sure that your advanced settings on your TV are set to "Enhanced" or "Full" or some other equivalent in the "external connections" setting. Lastly, your receiver likely has a specific mode for high speed connections. My Yamaha TSR 5810 has two modes, select the appropriate high speed mode. Once connected, it is flawless. Oh, and the aerial screen savers are amazing.

review_text: WHAT I LOVE:-Apple has more 4K rentals than Roku, and any other on-demand provider-User Interface is intuitive and in beautiful 4K-Siri has never been more useful pulling up movies and tv shows on demand-Netflix and Amazon 4K content looks terrific-Supports Bluetooth headphones and doesn’t have audio lag when watching movies-Apple remote is WiFi based, and doesn’t require line of sight to operateWHAT I HATE:-Apple Remote layout is unintuitive and the built-in touch surface often lags and kills the user experience. Also, I can’t figure out why they couldn’t add “previous/next” buttons. If you watch movies with the lights off, you have to double check you’re not holding the remote upside down and push the wrong buttons. This is Apple TV’s biggest weakness is the poorly designed remote.-YouTube on Apple TV still doesn’t support 4K. Hopefully this gets fixed in an update.-Sometimes non hi-definition content through Netflix and Amazon Prime looks worse compared to their Roku versions. Hopefully this gets updated.-Compatibility with universal remotes is a nightmare. Using my WiFi based Logitech universal remote is nightmare. It works half the time. If the Apple TV has been off for a few hours, my Logitech remote wont be unable to power it on.-Cannot play content from a usb thumb driveCOMPARED TO 4K ROKUCOST OF 4K CONTENT: APPLE WINSI own a 4K TCL television with built-in Roku. It has decent movie selections for purchase, but very limited selection of 4K rentals.Roku movie rental prices can also be misleading. Sometimes you’ll see a cheap movie rental, only to discover the low price only applies to the HD version, and then you’ll see the 4K version requires you to buy the movie at full price.I should also point out, on a Roku device, movie rentals and purchases are done through third party apps like Vudu, Fandango, etc. I’m generalizing them all as Roku movies.I invested in Apple TV 4K because it offers more 4K rentals. I’m not a fan of purchasing 4K movies for $19.99.If Apple has a movie for sale that isn’t yet available to rent, they often show you the date when it will be available to rent. That’s just considerate.USER INTERFACE: APPLE WINSThis may seem like a petty complaint (and it is) but it annoys me that Roku menus aren’t in 4K. It doesn’t take advantage of the 4K resolution.REMOTE: ROKU WINSRoku’s remote is so much better than Apple TV. Layout is terrific. Mine came with my TV as Roku is built-in. The only downside Is it has dedicated buttons for apps that no one uses (like starz, sling, Hulu), and you can’t reassign those buttons to perform other functions.I wish my Roku TV came with the WiFi version of this remote as the IR signal is often getting blocked If I don’t line it up properly. But I will say it does play nicely with my WiFi Logitech universal remote.

review_title: Great buy if you have a big iTunes movie library - otherwise poor value.
review_text: My first Apple product, but decided to return it. It is a very high quality and powerful streaming device but poor value if you have little iTunes content.Offers 4K, HDR and Dolby Vision. Dolby Atmos will be available with TVOS 12 in this fall 2018. I upgraded to the Beta TVOS 12 and that did provide Dolby Atmos through the VUDU app, but there was no iTunes content with Atmos at the time of my testing.I have a Denon 12 speaker Dolby Atmos system connected to an LG OLED TV which also provides 4K, HDR, and Dolby vision, and Dolby Atmos, through the same streaming apps - VUDU, NETFLIX, Amazon, etc,, although NO iTunes access. I also use Nvidia Shield for all my local content since the Nvidia provides full Lossless bitstream audio passthough. The Apple TV only provides lossy audio, or PCM, and it appears there are no plans to change that.The only substantial benefit to this ATV would be access to iTunes, but I have no native iTunes content. I was attracted to the Apple policy of atomatically updating any HD content to UHD. I do have a large VUDU collection linked to my MoviesAnywhere account, and that content did appear in my iTunes list, with the UHD versions (purchased in VUDU) appearing in iTunes as UHD, but all the other content remained as HD. The auto upgrade only applies to HD purchased via iTunes.This meant any HD to UHD upgrades would need to purchased anew. That works fine with VUDU, but iTunes would not allow me to purchase UHD versions of HD movies that were listed in my MoviesAnywhere account, it simply said I already owned HD and would not upgrade. Unlinking my MoviesAnywhere account made no difference, and "deleting" iTunes movies doesn't delete them but merely hides them, and that still prevented an upgrade. There was a trick that partially worked - you can gift a movie to yourself - this did indeed result in a UHD upgrade but it left my MoviesAnywhere entry for that movie as HD - sigh.Apple appears to be agressively adding new UHD content to iTunes, including upgrades to many older movies, perhaps more agressive than VUDU. Apple prices also appear competetive or lower than VUDU. But each company seems to have different deals with the studios. Apple has no Marvel UHD at this point - e.g. Guardians of the Galaxy, Thor, etc. VUDU has all those. And similarly for Lucasfilm - iTunes doesn't have UHD The Last Jedi, etc. All this might well change in the future of course. Each company offers a different selection of UHD content, but I suspect both will offer the same eventually, just like HD evolved. My movie choices easily favored VUDU which offered a greater UHD selection. VUDU also has the distinct advantage of running on almost any streaming device, whereas iTunes is severely limited. I couldn't see any significant benefit for a new investment in the Apple ecosystem for the occasional UHD movie not available on VUDU - I can wait.If you have significant iTunes content then the auto HD to UHD upgrades is a great deal and makes the Apple TV 4k a very good choice. If like me you have no iTunes content, then the ATV is an expensive unecessary item. Also if you have a Dolby Vision smart TV then you will have all the streaming Apps native to the TV making the Apple TV unnecessary, assuming you have no iTunes content.The touch pad remote though is horrific, fortunetaly my LG TV remote worked perfectly well on the Apple TV.The aerial screensaver is very nice - not sure it is worth the $180 price tag.

review_title: Premium streaming box, Only recommended for Apple centric people
review_text: This Apple TV is a beatifully engineered piece of hardware, it is a premium product at $199 for an over the top streaming box. Like all Apple hardware, the more of it you own, the more exponentially useful it will be to you. On the surface, someone could be hard pressed to find the value in this Apple TV. It's 3x-4x the price of similar products from Amazon and Roku, and at the end of the day it doesn't do much more besides playing games a lot better than any streaming box besides the Nvidia Shield TV (which has Nintendo Switch internals). But there is more to this device than that in my opinion.The A10X is an aging chip, but it's still leagues beyond what you would find inside Amazon or Roku's highest end devices. This allows you to play any games that support TVOS and primarily Apple Arcade which has something for everyone. You will need a controller for this, but Playstation and Xbox controllers are now supported. They look great on the big screen and the performance is really snappy. The Apple TV 4K actually has active cooling, this is not at all common for devices like this to have a fan.The other chief difference in this product is how it handles your data. Most TV streaming hardware is sold at a loss or for no profit and they make it up with the Ad revenue that they earn from tracking everything you watch and displaying ads to you. This Apple TV 4K has zero 3rd party ads of any kind and it collects as little data as possible, especially compared to Roku, Google, and Amazon. And Apple has only been increasing their protection of their users for privacy violating trackers. The App store on here has the same nutrition label privacy cards as what you see on iOS/MacOS for every app. In short, if you value you your online/digital privacy, this is the only streaming device that is worth owning.This also ties into a lot of Apple services like Photos, Podcasts, Music, Arcade. And it syncs it all up through iCloud. You can use your photos as a screen saver if you want, but the other ones are much better. There are some that are aerial views from the ISS, updated all the time. The screensavers are actually quite amazing on here.As a final note, I would like to point out that this device is now 3 years old, it will probably be refreshed with a new product in the coming months. If you don't care about playing games on your Apple TV and you need a new one now, then I think it's fine to still buy this model. The next one will probably have an A14 or A12Z chip on board, but this model is plenty capable for streaming 4K HDR content.If you are not deep into the Apple hardware ecosystem, you might not get the full $179-199 value from this product. If you are though, this product will not disappoint you.

On top of that, the box didn't recognize my wifi! I know -- hard to believe -- but that's what happened. All my computers recognize my wifi no problem. People bringing their computers over -- no problem. But Apple TV -- can't accurately identify my wifi! Unbelievable but true. But there's more. I went through the connection process multiple times, to make sure I hadn't typed in something inaccurately. No go. So then I called Apple TV support. I explained the problem -- and they hung up on me! DO YOURSELF A FAVOR -- DON'T WASTE $200 OR SO ON THIS THING.

You can choose which Apps you want on it rather than having all of them displayed.4. You can charge the remote via USB.What I dislike:1. The apps will occasionally freeze up and you have to delete it and reinstall it. I primarily notice this with the YouTube app.2. It doesn't always recognize my accent, but Alexa and Siri also have an issue with understanding accents too so this isn't unique to Apple.3. The remote sometimes (rarely) doesn't recognize touch when you try to swipe on the top part of it. But this is so rare that it's really just a matter of inconvenience.What I don't like is so minor that's it's really not even worth mentioning. I would buy the Apple TV for the remote alone because it's such a vast improvement over older models. I highly recommend Apple TV.

review_title: A high quality streaming device at an even higher price.
review_text: The Apple TV 4K has a nice solid build but unless you are an Applephile it can be bothersome in function for the sake of simplicity when it comes to turning it on the first time and downloading what you want. For streaming it loads pretty quickly but I was expecting lightning fast processing. It may be an issue of apps needing to be better streamlined. When the Apple TV 4K goes to sleep sometimes it gets hung up on itself when you turn it back on with blank icons, images, and missing information so you have to hit the Menu button to try and get it to reload. I tried a Roku Ultra prior to this and while this is faster it wasn't as fast as I was expecting. I have everything connected through ethernet (wired) so my internet speed is more than enough and you'll want yours set up the same way. Wireless should be good if you have fast enough speed. I had to set up an iTunes account just to be able to download apps on this thing, otherwise it locks you out from "purchasing" (downloading) apps. You have to purchase every app, even the free ones, so you need an Apple ID but it will not be complete without an iTunes account. Yeah, I'm one of the few people who doesn't have an iPhone or have iTunes as my go to music downloading software.The user interface is nothing special, but some people prefer it that way with just the icons for apps and settings. I haven't found a use for the Apple "TV" app, it seems to be based more on suggestions for things you have already downloaded. It's supposed to sync all of your apps and payment information for anything you pay for to stream. The Siri remote is decent for volume control as it uses your TV's infrared signal, it has Siri voice control which I've heard is awful so I don't use it at all. There is a menu button that functions as basic menu selecting and as a Back button. The home button selects either the Apple TV app or the main menu hub based on your options selection. There is a Play/Pause button, and a horrible touchpad instead of directional keys. You click on it for selections, but it's a real pain when watching a show and you want to fast forward or rewind. The easiest way to do this is to click on the direction you want at the end of the pad and keep clicking continuously. You can swipe with you fingers/thumb to proceed faster but it's easy to overshoot. There are options for touchpad tracking speed but it didn't make much difference in functional quality. I have it set on Fastest and it may take you a bit to get used to. I am being critical because it should have been better designed considering the cost for this streaming device.

Additionally, when I ask Siri to turn off the TV, the latter is not as reliable as an Alexa device. The biggest plus w the Apple TV box is it acts as an Apple Homekit hub. Whether it’s the previous gen w the touchpad or the new one w a ‘mute’ button, the remote’s just too small to be practical.Here’s the big irony: I like my ATV box but if it wasn’t there I’m pretty sure I wouldn’t notice and I’m not so sure about it’s value proposition. review_title: Great Streaming Device. Highly Recommended (but DO NOT buy from Amazon)
review_text: Amazing menus. Works incredibly fast. Picture and sound quality is extremely beautiful and superior. Runs multiple apps at once, switches between them seamlessly without re-buffering. Siri does voice search in every app, (unlike Alexa of Fire TV which only works on Amazon content). Gigabit Ethernet port works great if you have access to hard line. But the wifi is super strong and stays connected (unlike the Fire TV). Incredibly useful Home App connects content from multiple (participating) apps. Displays "Where You left off" and "Up Next" thumbnails at the top of the Home Screen. Up Next being the next episode of a series you are streaming, or the new episode of a series you favorited in a cable app.The super slim remote is very advanced and handy. Only needs to be charged every 6 months or so.This is a great product. But I would recommend you buy it at an Apple Store, Wholesale Club (Costco, Sams, BJs), Best Buy etc. NOT AMAZON. The one they sent me was defective. It was not poor design. It was negligence on Amazon's part. They shipped this device in a bubble mailer envelope not a box. Good thing Apple handles the warranty. I was able to go to my Apple Store and get a new one under the warranty. It works brilliantly.

review_text: It is an elegant product, like most Apple products (even though competitors are leaving Apple in the dust lately on a lot of features for phones and computers. C’mon Apple! I also find that the device is a bit slow for a 2019 piece of computer hardware. All this would be forgivable if there weren’t glaring problems with the picture quality of the content that apple is delivering. Depending on the source material, some movies look great after Apple’s conversion and some look absolutely awful. I’ve had to turn off the HDR in the Apple TV. I’ve read a lot of explanations on what Apple is doing to HDR10 movies vs. Dolby Vision movies, but I won’t bore you with it here. Suffice it to say that I expect ALL content being sent from the Apple TV to my brand new 4K Sony projector to look outstanding. Apple needs to get their sh** together. Everything does look very good coming from my 4K (non-HDR) Roku. If it weren’t for the fact that I’ve been stuck in the Apple ecosystem (desktops, laptops, iPhones) for a very long time (I started w/an Apple II Plus in 1979), I’d go with a cheaper alternative to the Apple TV 4K.

review_title: Great hardware with even better software provides a near perfect watching experience with not much to improve on.
review_text: Hands down the best user interface on any streaming device! Really liked the non-4K variant and this one is even better. Very responsive and the tilting effect applied to icons/artwork when scrolling is a nice little touch. HDR looks incredible. Aerial screensavers.. :)Remote does take some getting used to but I've come to enjoy using it. The one included with this model is slightly easier to use thanks to the tactile ring around the Menu button. Feels considerable better in the hand compared to other device remotes thanks to it's materials and build quality.One small complaint would be Apple not allowing more app developers to feature content on Siri suggestions or inside the TV app. Would be great if my Plex content could be accessed the same way Netflix or iTunes can. Maybe in the future an update will allow this but kind of doubt it.By far my top feature and reason for recommending would have to be the clean interface and home screen. Used a Nvidia Shield in the past which was okay but greatly prefer this. Tried the 4K Fire TV for not even a week before concluding that the constant suggestions/ads everywhere was not my thing (even as a Prime member).Though it probably doesn't matter much to most people I would have also liked support for Dolby Atmos and DTS-X audio formats. Apparently Dolby Atmos could be coming in the future over a software update though.Apple TV 4K has really improved my viewing experience especially when finding what to watch. I'll eventually be adding one to each TV in the house.

review_text: Its 'ok' - in that all of the bugs from the ATv gen 3 are fixed (since Apple isn't updating the older firmware and those older units will start hanging up after streaming a few things). The interface though- focused on flashy graphics that add little value, and the remote is a disaster.Programmed the IR codes into my universal remote and that helps. The Apple silly notion of hard coding some things (mark all as watched) as a 'long press' which cannot be programmed into a universal remote, is still an issue. But hey, one gets a native YouTube app back (that was removed from the 3rd gen. Still, that app is demonstrably worse than the native iOS app on the phone, so one trades phone battery life (by not having to airplay) for a janky new interface that is out of sync with reality. <sigh> If only the big tech companies with all the 'smart people' could write some decent software for a change, that would great, m'kay.

review_title: Directvnow works great on this box
review_text: We purchased this to try with the Directvnow streaming service. We previously had been using a Roku Premiere which we found very glitchy and it had slow response time. The Apple TV 4 K box is a huge upgrade. Directvnow works great on this box, the guide is very very fast and almost no instances of the dreaded spinning square from buffering. That happened frequently with Roku. All of the other streaming services and apps work well also and I love how the Apple TV app pulls content in from all of your subscribed sources (Netflix, Amazon, Hulu, HBO, Showtime, etc.). Yes this is several times more expensive than Roku but for us it's worth it for the improved experience. The Roku product was maddening. Combined with the Directvnow streaming service which is super cheap for ATT subscribers, it is an excellent alternative to cable.

review_text: It is difficult to put into words my disappointment with Apple based on my experience with this product. To start, I have many Apple products and have always been very satisfied with, at the least, how Apple treats customers. I do believe that the core value of user centric design have been degraded in the post-Steve jobs era, but overall, I have been a satisfied Apple customer. Those days may be coming to an end.I purchased the Apple TV 4K in February of 2021. If the last two days had not occurred, I would have given a glowing review to this product. However, a couple of nights ago, I noticed the status LED was flashing rapidly and there way no output to HDMI. Suspecting a software update, I went to bed and left the unit alone. The following morning, the light was still flashing. I performed the known tests of rebooting the unit, trying a different HDMI cable and input, charging the remote, and trying to use the remote to reset the device. Seeing as how I could not get the HDMI output to work, reseting the Apple TV through the interface was a no go.So I contacted Apple and scheduled a support call. They confirmed what I already knew, and said it was either a software issue or a hardware issue. Innocently, I scheduled a time the next day to take the Apple TV 4K to the Genius Bar for troubleshooting. And here is where things went very wrong. The Genius Bar tech essentially repeated the troubleshooting I had already done, and then said they don't really repair Apple TV 4K, they just over to sell you a replacement at the same price as a new one, and they did not have one in stock to boot.And here is my problem, and where I see Apple failing to excel in several areas:1. Why not put a hard reset to factory default button in the hardware design? If you can't get to the UI, you can't reset the unit to factory defaults. If you use the menus, you can reset to factory defaults and no internet connection is required. This is a bad design decision, however one that may not have helped me.2. Why on earth would Apple send me down to the Apple store, wasting yet another hour of my time if they could not in fact, actually do any real additional troubleshooting? And on top of that, they do not really repair Apple TV 4K's at all? It makes no sense to waste the customer's time by making them spend even more time going to the Apple store when they full well know they can't fix an Apple TV 4K. If they had leveled with me before I wasted my time, I would have been much less disappointed in the whole experience.3. Unlike in the past, Apple had no interest in doing anything before me, besides selling me another full price Apple TV.Now I know for a fact you can repair Apple TVs 4Ks, provided the manufacturer will support repair by selling parts and chips. It appears Apple has chosen not to do this, which is both lame for right to repair, and ultimately contributes to wasteful consumerism where when something doesn't work, you just throw it in the garbage and buy another one. Apple is a hugely profitable company with billions of dollars in cash. Anything they wanted to do, they could do it. At the very least they could partner with some of the smaller repair shops for customers who want to repair their devices.Apple is choosing to tell a customer who owns tons of Apple products and has spent countless dollars on Apple products over the years that getting barely over a year out of a $150 piece of hardware is no big deal, and I should fork over more money to them as the solution to my problems. I have been invested in the Apple Ecosystem for a while, and have been planning to upgrade my MacBook because it is serval years old, as well as an eventual phone replacement. But Apple is falling down not thinking their design through, and taking a terrible approach to customer service. Apple used to be a standout brand in these areas, but apparently they want to be just a run of the mill company exploiting their brand name for money, the customer be damned.I guess roll the dice on this product if you like, but don't expect much out Apple if anything goes wrong.

review_title: Best picture, interface, App consistency, forget the remote use App on iPad instead...
review_text: I had issues with the Roku 4K, and I found the interface clunky and old. I found the Apple TV 4K too expensive, so I got an Amazon Wharehouse deal on one for the same price as the Roku Ultra. The Apple interface is MUCH better, the App performance more consistent, and the picture is better — noticably. One star taken off for the remote, I have no frickin’ idea how Jony Ive thought the remote was ready for prime time. It’s a train wreck. The concept is great, but the touch area needs to be much bigger, and less sensitive. You get used to it, but it still can be frustrating at times. Siri works well enough, and the App consistency much better. The aerial screensaver is incredible!UPDATE: I finally downloaded the Apple TV Remote App for my iPad. Suddenly, the touch area for the remote is huge! While the App isn't perfect, it does make-up for some of the shortcomings of the remote. It seems less sensitive (good!), and vernally easier to use. Sadly, you can't do everything the real remote does, but that could change. The other con would be the functionality is a bit different for each, so I use the iPad most often. I bet the App improves from here. Earth to Jony Ive. The Apple Spaceship Campus is done, fix the GD Apple TV remote !!!

review_text: I have a gen 2 that still works (actually better than this one). I bought this to take it RVing so I could stream from my phone to the Apple TV without a WiFi network. I ended up paying $10 more per month and making my phone a personal hotspot, so I haven’t taken it camping. However, this device has become virtually unusable in our den because of an odd glitch. When streaming Netflix or Amazon Prime, the video frame will either freeze, or just go black, and the audio will continue. We have invested a ridiculous amount of time rebooting the Apple TV, the router, switching from one app to the other, backing up or going forward a bit in the movie. Nothing seems to work. It is bug ridden. We’ve searched the web for solutions. Lots of people are experiencing the same problem, but I’ve not found anyone with a working solution. We don’t have any other form of TV other than streaming Netflix and Amazon, and the news apps. We end up going into the bedroom to use a Roku stick, which streams without issues.oddly, I can watch a movie from my phone or iPad and use the mirror feature and it will work fine. It’s just a hassle to use two devices when one should work. Since 2004 we’ve bought only Apple products, two 27” iMacs, a MacBook, tow iPhones and three iPads. I’m shocked That Apple has allowed this bug to go unresolved so long. It’s the first Apple product I wish I had never bought. I could have spent far less on Amazon fire or Roku and gotten better service.

review_text: This is the best media streaming box of them all (and I’ve tried them all, believe me: Roku, Amazon, Chromecast, etc.) It’s got the easiest interface of any of them and has the most 4K compatibility of any of them. A recent software update now lets you choose to match the media contents original frame rate and dynamic range, so it doesn’t automatically upscale everything to Dolby Vision or HDR. Though if you keep it on Dolby Vison or HDR, the color of the menus, screensavers, and non-4K video content does REALLY pop. I recently bought a 4K UHD BluRay player to go along with my new system that I’m building because I thought that even the best streaming box in the world wouldn’t compare against a physical hard copy. And that’s more or less true, but the Apple TV 4K’s picture is so good that the difference between a hard copy of something and it’s cloud-based counterpart is just barely perceptible. That’s a huge compliment to the ATV 4K. Get this, even if you don’t have a 4K TV yet and future-proof your entertainment system.

review_text: Where to begin. Well, the remote is just awful. So difficult to use and super sensitive. I had to find a YouTube video to assist me because there are very little instructions included. It took 5 minutes to plug everything in and over an hour and a half to setup accounts, etc. and it’s still not operational! It took 7 tries to connect to my Wi-Fi. I have a very reputable cable company and have had no problems connecting laptops, etc. I even called the cable’s customer service line to make sure the name and password for the Wi-fi were correct. It just kept saying it could not establish a connection. After that hurdle, the next was trying to connect my iPhone and link that account. Another fail, so I moved on to the manual setup. I tried entering my Apple id so I could start adding the essential apps needed to play back anything. You guessed it – could not locate my Apple id. I went to my PC and logged into iTunes and purchased one song just to verify the account was working. I gave up after several tried on the Apple TV. What a waste of money. At almost $200 (including the HDMI cables you need to purchase), boy was this disappointing. I can’t comment on the picture quality, because all I got to see were the menu pages. If you like getting frustrated easily, with absolutely no payoff, then this is the product for you. I’ll stick with my Amazon Firestick instead.

review_text: The first few days were fine, unit worked well. Then one day, when I opened the Direct TV Now app, I found there was sound but no video. A black screen. I reinstalled the app thinking that was the issue. Same problem. Found out Amazon and Netflix had the same problem. Restarted ATV, video came back and everything was fine. But then, when the TV has been off for a long time, like when I go to bed, the next morning I always have to restart it to watch any app. I tried a reset. Same problem. Called Apple, they said it could be the HDMI cable. Suggested I get the $30 Belkin on their website, which I almost did. But I couldn’t see how this would make a difference because it’s not as if the picture quality is bad. The picture is perfect once you can get it going. I would think it’s a hardware or software issue. Software is up to date. I looked online and found that a lot of people have the same problem and can not find a solution. And for those who bought the Belkin cable, it did not solve the problem. I have a Sony Bravia XBR900E and I noted a lot of people had this problem with their Sony TVs. Aside from this problem, I like it. It’s easy to set up, and easy to navigate. The remote has a touch pad, and you can recharge it with a lightening cable. Also, Siri works fine. However, for the amount paid, one really shouldn’t have to put up with any problems.UPDATE I contacted Amazon for tech support. They said to return the item. I was surprised because it was after the return period, but returned it anyway. They’ve deducted a $35 restocking fee from my refund! Nobody said anything about a restocking fee. So warning to anyone who has the same problem as me. If you’re think of returning it, don’t wait unless you want to blow 35 bucks.

review_text: I bought this for a business trip. I own an iPad and an iPhone and I have used the screen mirroring capability in the past at my friend’s house because she owned an Apple TV. She loved it and I was sure I would love it, too. It can stream popular apps like Netflix and Hulu and you can display content from your iPad to the screen. Perfect, right? It does everything I need it to do.So, why the one star? I own a Roku and set up is easy and I never had any issues. I bought the Apple TV because I thought it would be a better product. Instead, I found the remote to be awkward. It’s thin and narrow and you need to actually read the instructions to see how it works. It was too touch sensitive which I am told can be adjusted. The set up takes a while as you select language and country with a remote that’s awkward to hold and use. And, for whatever reason, I keep holding the darn thing upside down. You can download an app if you prefer the ease of the phone. I found myself just using the Roku while at home because it’s so dang easy to use. Now here I am on business trip and I want to watch Netflix. I plug this device in and it doesn’t work with the WiFi in my room because it’s public. I figure maybe I can just stream/mirror from my iPad. Nope. I get an error message. I called in coworkers to assist. We google, we unplug, we restart, and at some point have the Apple TV “forget” my phone and iPad. That was a mistake because it needs WiFi and it won’t even recognize my phone. It is now a $180 paperweight. My coworkers give me a sad look because they have no problems streaming from their Roku device. I was the idiot who did not do enough research prior to purchasing.Long story short: Apple TV is an expensive piece of dog doo. Stupid thin and narrow remote. Set up takes too long. Doesn’t work in hotel room so don’t bring this on business trips. I am sure someone will tell me otherwise and I will concede to operator error. But my coworkers had no issues setting up their Roku in a hotel room. Roku is also cheaper and will give you everything you need except mirroring your iPad. Buy a separate adapter for that and it will probably still be cheaper.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2018

review_title: My One and Only Entertainment Hub
review_text: I have used Amazon's Fire TV and my Smart TV's built-in apps. Neither of those compares to the ease of use of the Apple TV 4K. I held off my purchase of an Apple TV until it had 4K ability, and now that it does, it's one of the best entertainment purchases I've made in a while. While anyone can use this, the maximum benefit is for those who are in Apple's ecosystem and have an Apple ID.— SETUP —Set up is easy: plug in HDMI cable from box to your TV; plug in power cord; you can choose a wireless setup, but I hardwired mine with an ethernet cable for a more secure and reliable streaming connection. Sign in with your Apple ID and begin getting apps.— APPS —You will likely find all the apps you need for the streaming services you subscribe to. There's Netflix, Amazon Video, Plex, Movies Anywhere, Vudu, HBO GO, Showtime Anytime, etc. Each of them has worked faster and smoother than the same apps available on my Smart TV, and it's one of the reasons I'd rather use the Apple TV 4K to access content vs using my TV.— ITUNES —I used to buy digital movies on Amazon. I immediately transitioned to iTunes once they offered 4K videos at the same cost as HD—and, free 4K upgrades to already purchased movies. This was the number one selling point for me. And with the Movies Anywhere app, a majority of my movies are synced between Amazon and iTunes (and other services).— HDR —This is Dolby Vision and HDR capable. Unfortunately, I bought my TV right before HDR became a thing, so I have no need for it. If you try to play HDR content on a non-HDR TV, you will notice visible gradient banding (my best description of it) on the image. Fortunately, there are options in the settings to play content in SDR instead of HDR. There are also many other video settings if you know what you're doing.— REMOTE —Firstly, buy a sleeve case for your remote, like the elago R1 Intelli Case Apple TV Remote . You don't want to pay sixty bucks to replace it if you break the glass surface. The remote is amazing to use. It's responsive, it's simple to learn, and it can do voice search. If you have to type anything, you can link it to your phone and type from your phone as well.— SUMMARY —I've had this for eight months and I love using it. Yes, there is a premium cost over competitors but Apple TV 4K is so worth it (to me) for the design, usability, and convenience. Recommended.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2018
author: benjamin bannister

review_title: Amazing! Especially if you are in the Apple Ecosystem
review_text: I had the last model of the Apple TV before the 4k model and I didn't really use it that much because it wasn't that useful. I ended up just using my TV apps for most of my viewing but I go the 4k model free with a Direct TV NOW promotion. Boy, is THIS model SOOOOO much more useful than the last one. The main thing I love about this is the TV app, you can select shows that you like to watch and they will all show up in one interface and when a new show comes out for a selected show it will be shown here, so it makes it really convenient for catching up on shows. I also like that you can browse through moves and then set them to show up in the TV app so you can come back later when you are ready to watch them.I was worried about the remote, but I've now grown to love it. Yes, if you were forced to use the touch pad remote to always scroll through your content, it would suck, but you can simply tap on the touch pad to do single movements on the device that feels a lot more like traditional remote. Also, you can always program almost any other standard remote to work with your Apple TV if you prefer the feel of a more traditional remote.Siri also works SO well for finding shows, movies, turning on captions or rewinding 30 seconds or 1 minute easily to catch something you missed in your show. If you have Apple Music and your TV is set up to a stereo system, you can also use the Apple TV as really great music player and play music just by talking to Siri, which is really great.All in all, I think the Apple TV is the best streaming box especially if you are already in the Apple Ecosystem. You can control the TV with your iPhone or Apple Watch, steam content from your Mac or iPhone which is all really really great. For me, I now only use the Apple TV as my main streaming device, it is fast and responsive and has a great interface. It also makes it really easy to cut the cable cord and save so much money by simply streaming all your content and maybe using a service like Direct TV now, Playstation Vue or Sling for your live TV needs.I for sure would not hesitate to get this. It is worth the price but you might even be able to get it for Free if you pay for 3 months of Direct TV Now if they are still offering that promotion!

review_title: Think Twice - Better yet, Wait for the next generation
review_text: I've been an Apple TV user going back the the first generation and have upgraded with each new generation. My current Apple TV 4K 64GB unit supports a Dolby Vision/Atmos home theater system with 11 active channels. When it works properly, the UHD/Vision video resolution and uncompressed Atmos sound is unsurpassed. However, so far I'm disappointed in the quality of current model and hesitate recommending it.This is in fact my second unit. The first went defective after 11 months, just inside the warranty period - thank god. That unit mysteriously began locking up my network with what looked like a DOS attack. After a lot of component tracing and sleuthing, I finally proved to Apple that the LAN chip must have a bug. Thankfully they replaced the unit. The second unit also seems to display mysterious behavior. Periodically, streaming apps will lock up requiring me to reboot the unit. On occasion, it locks up so badly I've had to do a physical reboot by disconnecting the power.If I'm the only person with issues on two units - all I can say is I wish I had this kind of luck at winning the Lottery!Quality and bugginess notwithstanding, the new Bluetooth controller is the ABSOLUTE WORSE piece of electronics Apple has ever produced. Don't take my word for it, go to various enthusiast websites and do your own research. First, when picking up the controller in a dark room, there's no tactile way to know which side is top or bottom. As result you frequently end up doing something you didn't intend. The unit has a touch/click pad on the top that can be under sensitive, or oversensitive without rhyme or reason. It is used both to execute commands (press) as well as move forward/backward (slide finger or press the edges). Good luck with that. You simply have no idea what's actually going to happen when you use the controller.Overall, this is the most frustrating controller I've ever used, bar none. How frustrating you wonder? How about smash it against the wall and shatter it to pieces, anger management territory, frustrating?Rumour has it Apple plans to replace the controller with their next iteration of the Apple TV. Meanwhile, you can use the controller app on your phone or you can use an older controller from the previous gen Apple TV. Trust me either is a better option.My recommendation is wait for the next generation Apple TV with a new controller or try a different brand streaming device. Maybe by then they will have worked out the bugs.

author: Peter Hillegas

review_text: Pricey and whomever gave green light for remote should be fired. I will leave the remote alone for now. The interface of this device is gorgeous and simple to use. Setup a breeze. It is my main goto streaming device although I have Roku 4k and Amazon 4k firestick. I also love that when you purchase movies from ITUNES they upscale them to 4k for free. The 4k is beautiful and as I mentioned the screen saver pictures I can watch those for an hour because the resolution is spectacular. I use it to watch my NHL package, NFL Gamepass, and MLBTV package. Hbo, Showtime Netflix Hulu, Starz all streamed through this powerful device. I bought the mount and clamp to mount it to the top of my LG 55”4k tv because I wanted a clear line for the remote. I would like to take 3 stars off just for the remote. It is like a toy you would find in a Cracker Jack box. It has a small mouse pad you have to navigate with your big fat thumb. And if you want to fast forward through a commercial at only 10 second increments you have to be so dexterous to push the top right corner of the remote consecutively about 15x in a row, if you fail once and press the mousepad while pressing the top right corner your life becomes almost worth not living anymore. The marker on timeline freezes and you can then decide to press mouse pad and risk moving ahead 15 minutes and I have jumped too far ahead where I saw the outcome of the sporting event I was watching. Maybe it’s small because at this point I wanted to throw the remote through the tv but it’s so small it may not even crack the screen of the tv. It has no lights so if you watch tv in the dark like 99.99% of human beings, you cannot tell which end is up, the bottom half looks just like the mouse pad on top half, you can also easily press the Siri microphone option is you try to hit the menu button, now you have siri’s Attention and she waits for a command but she doesn’t know you accidentally pressed the microphone, so to make Siri go away you have to press the microphone again which since it’s dark you can’t see where that button is, it’s kind of like reading Braille, you have to just feel around for the menu button. You should have a flashlight handy if you are going to use this POS remote. I guarantee Steve Jobs would not have allowed this remote to ever be made or released to the public, but the streaming box is a work of art. 64GB is a ton of memory, if you have the money and want the most powerful streaming device available then buy this. But you can own two 4k Roku and a 4k Amazon firestick and still have $50 to use towards a dinner out on the town. The Screen Savers are conversation starters if you have guests over. And Apple did finally decide to let you know what you are looking at, just gently tap the mouse pad and it will let you know where on earth these beautiful shots are from, and they aren’t still shots, they are panning as if a slow drone is filming them, some are from the space station which really makes things real, wen you can look at our planet from space in 4k, awesome. I guarantee Neil Armstrong would have one of these devices just for this option. Most people would suffice with 32GB memory but I treated myself to the 64 as I was planning in tv to evolve and I might need that memory one day. Like i said, if price point isn’t a huge deal then buy this now. If you get angry easily don’t because the remote will make you want to smash a hole in the wall.

author: Pharmtech

review_text: I have apple TV's of second and third generation. Was looking forward to this one but sorely disappointed.Not all is bad. I like using the voice input option to set it up with login email address and password however my husband's voice input isn't always recognized, mine is. However it is easy to confuse and press the voice button instead of the menu button. They are both circluar and on the left side and that's annoying as they do two different things. We have gotten used to the touch bar area but that has taken time. I don't see any advantage to it really. Maybe it was cheaper to make than putting in FF and Rev buttons? We may be getting used to it but neither of us like using it over a button. It requires finger pressure continuously or intermittently in a specific area depending on what you want it to do.The worst thing about it is the need to constantly restart it and that is buried deeply in the settings menu. Why? Because the Ethernet connection is unstable and it constantly reverts to WiFi then has to choose between the 5G wifi signal or the lower one. With every change between WiFi SSID strengths the password has to be reentered and to get it back to Ethernet, it need to be restarted. It won't change over from the settings menu. Its a royal pain to have to reconnect it to the internet every time we use it so we disconnected the Ethernet cable and removed the 5G wireless SSID signal so that only one SSID is broadcasted. That seems to have fixed the problem with apple TV requiring us to enter a WiFi password each time we use an app.Unlike a computer where you can switch users, on Apple TV different household members have to log in on the apps. It means you are constantly logging in and out to to be able to use your playlists and pick up from where you last watched a program. Not only that, but even after setting up and logging in, it's not uncommon to have to resestablish the right to use them by requesting a code be entered after logging into a browser on another device.Another major problem is the Audio has to go through the HDMI or BT. The idiot who designed the BT soundbar connection put that under BT devices (not the audio settings) and it was a nightmare to find (no manual) but either way it's buried and a pain to get to each time you turn on the Apple TV. It remains paired but as soon as the TV input is changed or the TV is turned off the Apple TV defaults to audio over HDMI. If your TV sound is as bad as ours and goes through a soundbar instead you are stuck with using a BT connection that is dropped. To save money, on this version, they dropped the external optical sound output for a cable.Apps are not refreshed and the only way to refresh some, like Fubo, is to dig into settings, restart the Apple TV and then go back into setting, find BT devices and reconnect the BT sound bar. On this version the apps are locked so that an iPad or computer is required to reconnect their function. Much like an iPhone or iPad, each app has its own log in.There are days when I decide it's a pleasanter experience to stream over the third generation Apple TV from my phone or iPad or just watch from my iPad. I was deathly sick for 3 weeks after buying Apple TV so the return period was up by the time I was able to get it set up, sorted out and identify the problems. It does work and everything I have mentioned is "expected behaviour". I would certainly have returned it and continued happily using my lesser generation Apple TVs despite the fact that they do not support the newer apps like SmugMug and Fubu. It is also hard to figure out how to install apps and move them and delete them. There is no manual so I had to search You Tube and tutorials to figure it out.I was hoping the last update (Feb 2020) would correct the behavior of not keeping the BT sound bar connection as my preferred audio default or the Ethernet cable as my preferred connection type but no such luck. I have given apple feedback on these issues.There are a couple of improvements. It is much easier to move the apps around the screen and after hitting the restart command it takes only a few seconds (we have a FiOS connection).

review_title: Best Streamer but Will Cost You More
review_text: This is in my opinion the best streaming box of any that I have used. My experience includes owning and using Roku, Fire TV, and Chromecast as a comparison. The greatness starts with the outstanding flexibility of voice searches with Siri. There is a lot you can do with the voice search that you cannot do with any other device. As an example, I can ask for movies or shows specific to a service like, "horror movies on Netflix" and it will show content just on Netflix. If I have a TV subscription with sports services I can say, "watch the Chicago Bulls" and if there is a live game on an app I have installed the Apple TV will automatically go to that app and start playing the Bulls game. It is these kind of features that elevate the Apple TV experience beyond the normal TV experience.The Apple TV app is also a great source for finding "free" content on the apps you have installed. You will find integrations with apps like Hulu, Prime Video, Tubi TV, and a host of TV everywhere apps. The biggest miss here is Netflix, but the voice search makes up for this. The TV app is also the source I go to for Live sports with my Hulu Live TV subscription I have access to apps like ESPN, NBC Sports, and Fox sports. The games on these channels integrate with the TV app so you can see what live sporting events are on. You also get notifications when games are starting for your favorite teams and updates on when games are close. These notification show up in the upper right hand corner of the screen and keep you informed on what is going on with your favorite sports teams. It is another feature not found on any other streaming devices.There is more here that I could talk about and if you just use the Apple TV as a normal streaming box you will be missing out on some pretty awesome features. I could probably write a small book of the little things I have learned how to do with the Apple TV. If you want the premium experience, I think this little box is worth the money, whether it is the 4K version or the older 1080P one, both are the best streamers available right now.

review_title: One of the most frustrating pieces of electronics I’ve ever used
review_text: I had used an older Apple TV 4 years ago and had really enjoyed the interface, it was intuitive and navigation was easy. The 4K model is a nightmare. I thought the track pad would be a no-brainer but it is probably responsible for most of the frustration of using this device. I was expecting the trackpad to be as accurate as the screen on an iPhone but it is so unresponsive it’s a miracle I haven’t snapped the remote in two in frustration. To use the trackpad to navigate during a show feels like it registers inputs 50/50 at best- either there is no response or the response is not what you want and you end up doing something like rewinding or exiting a show you're watching.. The controls/gestures are also not intuitive and once you think you have it figured out the trackpad either doesn’t respond or you get sent back in a loop. Maybe it’s me but swiping left and right sometimes gets recognized as up and down and up and down sometimes does not even get recognized. The design of the remote is especially frustrating, it’s so small and slippery that it gets lost, misplaced or camouflaged anywhere and the trackpad actually ends up being too sensitive at the wrong times so when you sit on it or brush against it you end up changing programs, fast forwarding etc because it doesn’t need to be pointed at the Apple TV box to work. The remote is also symmetrical in that when you grab it you can’t tell which side is up and you will hit the wrong button and instead of searching you are now being sent outside the app to the main menu. There’s no fast forward or rewind buttons. It’s up to you to thumb wrestle with the trackpad to find how far forward, backwards or in my case out of the show you want.The main menu interface is fine. All the apps are in a row like apps are. The interface issues are in app and in knowing if you need to press the trackpad, swipe up, swipe down or throw it across the room. There is a Menu button as well as a TV shaped button. If you can tell me which button means Back, Return, Menu, Power and Exit then maybe the Apple TV is for you.If you want a streaming device just get a Roku. It’s cheaper, more intuitive and will do everything you want.

review_title: Didn't watch regular TV for a month after I got this
review_text: The Apple TV is the best way to watch Amazon Prime content I have found. Its UI is fast and attractive to use. It loads Amazon content in a second, and play it at very high HD quality. I was using a Tivo before to watch Amazon, and the Apple TV is (literally) ten to twenty times faster than Tivo. Apple TV's Amazon Prime content looks like lightly compressed 1080p content, while Tivo's Amazon Prime content looks like upscaled 480p content.Btw, the 32GB version is more than enough storage for most users. The additional storage is not useful for TV watching, it's for people who want to download a lot of very large games or hundreds of apps.The Apple TV can do more than watch Amazon videos. You can install third party apps built just for it, though Apple has said that it would eventually like the Apple TV and iOS devices to share apps. You can ask Siri for a bunch of stuff like the weather, though not as much as you can ask for on a phone. The YouTube app is simple but fast and works well too.The Apple TV also serves as a Homekit hub. There's a one to two second delay with a typical setup of a motion detector turning on a light. The UI for Homekit on iOS is unfinished and harder to use than usual Apple products. There are far fewer Homekit devices available on the market than other standards. Despite these problems, it works fine as a home automation hub as long as you don't mind the slow response time when you combine devices.

review_title: A noticable upgrade from Chromebox+Smart TV
review_text: I have a relatively recent Sony TV and we watch primarily Netflix and local content from NAS. I'd been using the TV's own player for Netflix and a Chromebox with LibreELEC for other stuff. Unfortunately the TV is incredibly slow to boot, it takes over a minute to the point where the first video starts playing. The other option, the Netflix plugin in OpenELEC/Kodi has a horrendous UI, even if/when it works. Also, the Chromebox couldn't control the TV, which was fairly inconvenient. Therefore I decided to look for a TV box that would substitute both.I had a few simple requirements, all of which I thought would be/should be easy to meet: 1. fast wake-up and menu navigation, 2. usable by my wife and kids, 3. a stable and usable remote with TV volume control 4. support for Kodi and Netflix 5. support for 4k in both Kodi and Netflix (judders due to frame rate mismatch really annoy me) 6. support for 4k in both Kodi and Netflix.It turns out that Netflix is really picky about what devices they approve for 4k playback, so requirement #6 eliminated all, but a handful of options (primarily Fire TV, Roku, Apple TV, Nvidia Shield). Of these, only the Apple TV and Nvidia Shield comes close to meeting the other points. The Shield fails on Netflix frame rate switching, while the Apple TV kind-of fails on Kodi support. Finally I decided that I'd rather settle for the pared-down Kodi experience that is sold in the app store under the name "MrMC" and got the Apple TV (I know I could side-load the full Kodi version, but with the certificate expiring every week it is a maintenance nightmare).So far I'm very happy with the Apple TV. It is a typical Apple experience, the customization possibilities are severely limited (especially compared to the Chromebox), but all the necessary functionality is there, and what is available works perfectly out of the box. I was positively astonished about the HDMI-CEC support. Not only did it work, but it correctly auto-detected every configuration parameter, including key mapping. The TV switches on and off in sync with the Apple TV, and I can even use the playback control buttons on the TV remote to control the Apple TV.

review_text: 2 Probs with this machine. First, I guess sometime after our old 3rd gen apple tv, they decided to go cheap on their antennas. At first I thought it was cool, and so much easier swiping just right and left on the alphabet rather than up and down and left and right when typing stuff in with the old remote. But it's also annoying to be constantly swiping accidentally if you pick it up or it slides across the sofa, so I have mixed feelings about it. review_text: I’ve been Apple person for nearly two decades. I have stuck with them in spite of the higher cost than their competitors because I appreciate the durability and interoperability of their products. That all changed today. I purchased this device through my university bookstore last January and it has worked well since then.Two days ago, my tv screen flashed green and the AppleTV crashed and restarted. I thought it was strange, but continued on. Once the os had come back up, I tried to navigate back to where I had been in Netflix. The moment I tried opening Netflix, it crashed and restarted again. I tried everything: hard reboot, reset, reset and reinstall tvOS (most of those things many times).Finally I called Apple and they told me to do all of the things that I had already done. The operator I spoke to volunteered early on that my device was out of warranty and that the cost of repair was roughly the cost of purchasing a new device. While I appreciated his candor, the fact that Apple does not empower a senior tech support person to offer a repair or replacement for a device that is two months out of warranty has permanently soured me on this company.The AppleTV 4K costs nearly four times as much as comparable products from Amazon and Google. I was willing to pay that last year because I expected that the product would, like the many other Apple products that I have purchased over the years, last for a long time. However, when the hardware abruptly and fatally failed just a short time after the warranty expired and Apple customer service declined to offer a replacement on a fairly new device to a long-time customer, I decided hat it’s time to switch my technology life away from Apple.I just purchased a Fire Stick 4K for $50, and I am optimistic that it will interface with the Echo (which I presently just use as an alarm clock) with the same ease that my iPhone used to interface with my AppleTV.

review_title: Great Device to Stream Sports - Faster than Other Streaming Devices
review_text: Prior to purchasing my Apple TV 4K (did not purchase it on Amazon, so this is purely a product review), I'd owned a Roku Stick and a Chromecast. The primary apps I used were MLBTV, ESPN, Fox Sports Go, Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime Video. I thought both of them were great, but I knew I needed something faster. When my hometown baseball team wasn't playing, I liked to switch between baseball games on MLBTV. The Roku Stick and Chromecast simply do not have the hardware required to do this seamlessly. I decided I needed an upgrade.There aren't many surprises when you take it out of the box. It's a thick, squarish box with rounded edges. The remote is extremely thin, and there's a power cord. Disappointly no HDMI cable (wtf Apple!). Turning it on and connecting it, I noticed immediately how much faster it was than my Roku Stick and Chromecast. I also noticed there were many benefits I really enjoyed that I didn't expect. The ability to connect my AirPods and Bose headphones wirelessly to the Apple TV 4K was amazing. When my roommate was asleep in the next room, I could always switch to wireless headphones to ensure the audio output wouldn't wake him up. Using my iPhone as a keypad was also a huge plus. Gone were the days where I had to press button after button to type my email and password (and hear that annoying sound) on the Roku Stick!The remote was the only downside out of the box. It's tiny and super easy to lose. It's also very temperamental. If you have the remote sitting next to you on the armrest of a chair and accidentally brush up against the touch portion of it, it might disrupt your programming. However, the ability to use your iPhone to control the Apple TV (somewhat) makes up for this.Overall, I think your satisfaction will depend on how well the developers did developing your favorite app for the Apple TV. I can always count on MLBTV to have a top-notch app, but I ran into issues with the NBC Sports app. Playback was fine, but the audio differential between gameplay and commercials was unbearable. I even wrote to them, but they still didn't do anything to fix the issue. Before you purchase, I'd take a look and check out the reviews of the apps you're interested in. If you are an MLB fan, this is the best device to stream games on, hands down.

review_title: It's an Apple product.... but it could still be a little better IMO
review_text: If you're considering Apple TV 4K you probably know all the good stuff... Like all apple products, it's a premium device with excellent hardware, interface, apps, picture/sound quality and integration seamlessly with other IOS devices. It does all the stuff you already know Apple does well.That said, there's a couple of things that aren't so great (other than the price tag).1. The remote (this is a big one). It's premium for sure, but it's not user friendly at all, which really hurts the user experience.It's tiny and unergonomic, which makes it difficult to hold and navigate, and very easy to lose (easily falls between the sofa cushions, etc...). The touch interface is difficult to master, so you're constantly swiping past your selection or accidentally swiping when you try to click. It makes the user experience frustrating and time consuming, and contributes to "hand fatigue".Much like an iPhone it has a built-in rechargeable battery that is not serviceable. This means you'll need to recharge the remote every few weeks, which can be inconvenient, and if the battery ever fails the remote will need to be replaced.It does not have mute or power on/off buttons . Yes it support HDMI-CEC which can turn control your TV and other A/V equipment (but only if your equipment supports that feature) . Personally, I'd appreciate dedicated mute and power buttons.Basically they over engineered the remote, making it really "cool" but a nightmare to use, and the sad part is that it probably added $50 to the overall cost of Apple TV.2. Like all Apple devices each Apple TV must be associated with an Apple ID (account), but unlike an iPad, or iPhone, an Apple TV is not necessarily a "personal" device.You can switch between your families Apple accounts, but you have to navigate several layers into the settings menu to select the appropriate account. This should be an easy selection at the top menu, or home screen.At the end of the day, If you have a 4k TV, it's probably a "smart" TV, in which case your TV can do most of what this Apple TV 4K does (with the exception of access to Apple's ecosystem). But if you're an Apple household and want access to your Apple content on your home entertainment system, then Apple TV is the solution. If not there's better options for a fraction of the cost.

review_title: A Big Step Forward for IPTV
review_text: The Apple TV 4K is definitely a 5 star product for certain people. You fit the bill if: You have a 4K TV, are heavily invested in iTunes, are willing to subscribe to Netflix or premium channels/already have cable and have a strong (above 20 MBPs) internet connection.UI: As per most Apple products the UI is pretty dang flawless. Navigating is easy and the Siri remote works wonderfully and is actually pretty fun to use.Apps: There are a TON of apps! A lot of them with free content. Comet, Shout Factory, Midnight Pulp, Mascot and Waves to name a few. If you have Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu, etc. then this is definitely the best experience for all of them. Most work really well with Apple's "TV" app for endless bingeing. Not to mention: there's a boatload of games and other cool apps. Everything from webcams to shopping. You'll be surprised at what you can find on the App Store. AirPlay is a total boon as well. You can stream anything on your iPhone, iPad or Mac to the Apple TV... Even your home screen!Audio/Visual: One of my favorite features of the aTV is how highly intelligent it is in regards to different resolutions, frame rates, aspect ratios and dynamic ranges of video sources. Since it's recent software update the aTV is able to automatically switch all of these to give you the original content unaltered. Pretty neat. One big bummer is the lack of lossless audio. Still no DTS-HD, Dolby TrueHD or Atmos. A lot of other set-top boxes can already do this...Device: The box itself is super slick and small. It disappears well into your entertainment center and is completely silent. The ethernet port lives on for all you hardwire fans. It still has an IR receiver and it can "learn" commands from older remotes. Perfect for controlling A/V receivers and commands sent from Logitech Harmony devices or other universal remotes. The bad news is TOSLINK is no longer... Sorry stereo receiver folks.Overall: I'm really happy with my Apple TV 4K. I can definitely tell that this is the direction TV will be heading in the future and it's a good start. If you're like me and are still really into live TV and DVR functionality it probably won't replace your TiVo/cable provider box (unless you opt for DirecTV Now) but it's definitely a big step forward.

review_title: RIP Apple TV (Why, and survival tips)
review_text: Sadly this is my first negative review for Apple. Ever. I’ve enjoyed their products for a very long time. It this one, no. I’m technical. These are verified facts on a Meraki router.The unit will spin endlessly not telling you it dropped the network connection. It will stall and 100% for sure Apple on the title you’re viewing isn’t steaming. Pick another title, bam. Go back. No. It will stop getting bandwidth at all from Apple but will if you reset it. It wull go berserk and consume 65mbs continuous for 14 hours straight (I halted it) if you set for daily screensaver updates. Signed up for HBO Now? That app will now force you to go register on their site. When you do chokes and says you’re already registered under your email (duh) but you’ll be stuck then use another email account. So you’d think you could log into HBO Now stand-alone, right? No dice. No worries though you’ll still get billed via your AppleID. The remote. Epic total fail. But no problem use an older remote. Solved. Got an iPhone and want to sling the screen like you used to? Awesome for up to ten minutes. It will drop you. Every time. Couple of survival tips next. Fist set the screensavers to never download. Second turn off all podcast and background app updates. Turn off auto update. If you don’t and you have a data cap you’ll be sorry. Even if you have a pro router and enough bandwidth of you don’t it will suck so many cycles you will have sluggish behavior everywhere else. (That’s on 150 fiber!). This device will also drop and reconnect to your network nearly continuously: you can fix that though if you can set up your network for only WPA2. RIP a favorite vendor. especially after the battery code fraud atop this epic time suck. (All new content is going through Amazon; that just works, like Apple once did)

There are some superior features. For example, I can scroll through the DirectvNow menu very efficiently than holding down Roku's button. I also found out how to delete apps. review_title: Still the worst Apple product out there. Don't buy it!
review_text: You want to be frustrated every time you sit down to watch TV? This product is for you. You want a remote that does the opposite of what you want it to do? This product is for you. You want to be reminded how much Apple design has gone down, this is the perfect product for you because no actual design went into the making of this thing.I’m a lifelong Apple fan and bought this from Apple directly but I now spend my days wanting to the stupid remote at my TV every time I try to use it. I find myself yelling at the TV and cussing out Apple EVERY. SINGLE. DAY! Hope lots of people get fired over this thing. DIE APPLE TV!Some of the main problems include the remote being too sensitive or not sensitive enough. The touch pad does whatever it wants to do. When trying to select any app on Apple TV, the first two tries are usually incorrect since the remote slides to the nearest app that next to the one you want to open and then opens that app that you didn’t want.The menu button is actually a back button (or the screensaver button or who knows).The other button with the TV icon is also a back button, a menu button, or who knows. Basically does the first thing as the first one, but not really… just enough similar stuff to confuse you and make the remote the least intuitive thing. You have to really really REALLY FOCUS AND CONCENTRATE when you’re using this terrible product, otherwise you’re going to spend time exiting apps, clicking on menu options you didn’t mean to, restarting your device, throwing your hands up in the air… and giving up completely on watching whatever you wanted to watch on TV.Also, what's up with the UX for apple TV? you swipe right to select the app on the right, but if you want to completely close an app (double clicking on the TV icon), sliding right makes things go the opposite direction than when you're in the main screen. Why would apple do this? To confuse you, to piss you off, or most likely because their design team phoned it in while sipping liquor from a remote island.Youtube app.... let me not even get into how bad this is. It's obviously an Apple ploy so you don't log into youtube that often. All i know is that Apple makes it 1000% harder for you to watch youtube and it makes me hate Apple for that because no matter what they do I’m still going to watch Youtube even if I have to do it away from my Apple TV.Listening to music is also terrible. The menus are so bad that when trying to select a song or playlist it will take 2 to 3 attempts. Your music library is on the right hand side of the screen, but when you first open iTunes you're actually on a different tiny menu at the top of the screen. Intuitively I scroll to the right because i see my playlists there - but if I scroll to the right, the stupid apple TV takes me to the next menu option on the tiny menu at the top - so now i have to try again remembering to first scroll down then left (even though in Western society we read things left to right followed by top to bottom). Same things happens on the Youtube app, except that when you switch menus for any reason (mostly on accident thanks to the bad UX design), your video suggestions change and anything you might have wanted to watch is gone and now you have to go to your phone or computer to try to find it.Anyways, the Apple TV 4K is a work in progress like it’s always been. Save your money and yourself from frustration by not buying this thing.
