review_title: Another slick, powerful Apple device. Fancy remote can be fiddly.
review_text: We replaced our older Amazon Fire box because we were considering limiting our cable television to streaming, and the Amazon box apparently doesn't support the Spectrum app. We decided not to go that way, but the Apple TV has been a good unit.The Apple TV was reasonably simple to install although I ran into an issue where it would not accept a splitter I had on our older TVs last HDMI input to select between a DVD player and the streaming box. Apparently the Apple TV demands a lot of throughput, and we got a higher-quality cable and removed the splitter. Once on, it walks you through the process of setting everything up with voice prompts, etc. Hard to mess it up.The picture is amazing. Razor-sharp and noticeably better than the cable box. Our older Sony TV doesn't support 4k, but it I remember it advertised being able to interpret higher-resolution signals to some extent and it's just stunning through the Apple TV.Apple's interface is more complicated than the Amazon box, with several layers you sometimes have to dig through to get to what you want, although that's a pretty quick process of hitting the "menu up" or "home" button. It does sometimes have an issue with Apps (like Amazon) where you're logged in already and if you've left that window open, you have to go back to it or close the first window before selecting the app. It all works, but it's more to deal with than the simpler Amazon interface.Ameliorating the complexity is Apple's super-powerful voice-interface. It does more than at least the old Amazon box did, turning captions on and off (handy) and searching, although sometimes it won't "find" something unless you're already in the right app for the right streaming service. Unlike Amazon's system, where you can just speak at the (newer) devices or your Echo unit, you have to push a microphone button, but it's also cool that you can literally whisper into it and it will "hear" you perfectly.Speaking of the remote, the tiny, thin, rechargeable Apple remote is cool, with its sleek aluminum back and fancy touchpad, but that touchpad can be fiddly, sometimes refusing to fast-forward or reverse if you haven't pressed the edge in exactly the right way. And just brushing your arm across it inadvertently can start issuing commands when you only wanted to pick up your drink. Offsetting that a bit is that if you have Apple devices like iPhones or iPads lying around, the devices will prompt you to use them as remotes, which also lets you type on a keyboard to put in long passwords, a real pain on other systems where you have to painstakingly pick out individual characters on the screen. I am seriously considering a 3d party remote to get some simpler hard buttons though.There are more advantages for Apple folk. You can stream photos from your computers, which the Apple TV spookily prompts you to link to. And you can easily stream material from your iPhone or iPad to the screen, which is handy when something is only available online.We like the Apple TV and will be keeping it. It's got the usual sky-high Apple quality, tech and slick features, and the usual Apple quirks that can be frustrating. However, having set up the fancy new Amazon Cube for my parents, which lets them control their entire entertainment system by speaking at their Echo devices, I'm sure I did the right thing getting them that instead, and can see how others might prefer it.Five stars. No-brainer for Apple devotees; maybe not the best if you don't have other Apple devices or don't like tech with a bit of a learning curve.

review_title: Superb picture and sound quality, range of apps and channels surpasses the Roku
review_text: I was looking to replace a Sky HD+ service and to be honest to replace some less than stellar roku boxes. I used to love the Roku 2 as it gave the best range of apps and channels and was fairly easy to configure and use, unfortunately from version 3 of the Roku box onwards I’ve either struggled to connect to the TV, achieve anywhere near decent picture quality or pair the renote. So enter the Apple 4K TV device, it has the typical IOS interface but allows connection of Amazon Prime, Netflix, Britboz, UKTV Play etc plus of course Apple TV. Driving the interface with the supplied remote takes a fair bit of getting used to and defaults whenever you press a key it wasn’t expecting to open the Apple TV app which can be a bit irritating, the good news is you can drive the Apple box using your existing TV remote (or at least I could using my Phillips Ambilight TV remote).The best part about this device is the absolutely stunning picture quality - when it says 4K it means it and the sound is pin sharp too. The device even set my HDR configuration on my TV to display the picture in the best way possible.To top it off you even have Siri available on the remote, so if like me you can’t work out how to open and close apps or ‘show episodes’ rather than play the next one in a box, set Siri understands most garbled commands and is far more forgiving and intuitive than Amazon’s Alexa when you don’t use the exact command it’s looking forIf you are considering this product to be a little expensive, like most Apple tech it is, but the benefits are worth it, and go for the highest storage you can it improves the flow of programs you are streaming. On the downside don’t expect any glitches you do find (and there are a few for example getting it to show-up as a HDMI feed when in sleep mode) to be fixed any time soon - that’s just not the Apple crew’s jam

author: MICHELLE K.

review_text: Where to start. I have both the Fire Cube and the Apple TV. Both have their pros and cons.When it comes to setting Resolution and Hz Apple Wins. Not sure why Amazon keep hidden the 24p and 25hz options. Set 4K 60hz SDR and leave it at that. Amazon's Automatic 4k does not choose a 4K resolution or forced set to 4K@24Hz never sticks.Match Frame rate and Dynamic range. This is in apples favour. It works but apple does have a an actual 24 fps problem (not 23.976 but 24.00 if the content is true 24p and not NTSC 23.967 or 23.98). They match it but at the set resolution of your box. It will not match resolution just the FPS of the content and match the dynamic range of the content so if it's Dolby vision it will kick up to Dolby Vision. Amazon could learn from them on this front.Audio hmm for a 4K product this should be able to bitstream and not output everything as PCM. This is where Amazon wins as my receiver should be able to decode it.Apps. Again Amazon wins. There is much more apps on the Amazon fire TV then there is on the Apple TV. More choice can be better.Remote. I do get along with the apple remote but it could of been better. I prefer actual buttons and this is where the amazon remote wins. Buttons that are for the actual command does wonders.The interface I do find I like Apple's TV app more. I seem to be able to find things a bit more easier and it's good on recommendations.Each has their pros and cons. If Amazon's Match frame rate and resolution worked with third party apps or when I set the resolution and remained set when I set it to 2160p@ 24hz it would not be a problem. Amazon need to step up and stop with just 50 or 60hz only options. Each has it's pros and cons. so the choice is yours.
date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on May 14, 2020
author: StargazerUK

review_title: Simplistic streaming device for IOS users
review_text: This is a great streaming device for us Apple IOS users, and for those who have a large iTunes library it's a no brainer. The design is simple but beautiful, the inputs you need at there and work first time every time.This is the 3rd Apple TV I've owned and setup wasn't as easy as the others, Lag was crazy at first... which wherever I searched came up with the same solution.... fix your network. I did this, and it didn't help. What I did realise after looking through the settings extensively, is that the device after doing its initial set up, didn't realise my TV was 60hz and defaulted to 50hz. It also did not set itself to Chroma 4:2:2 which I have the correct cable for.After manually setting up the Apple TV myself all lag disappeared, and the picture was visibly clearer and smoother.Everything else is standard Apple, integration in to the eco system is seamless and work flawlessly.Apps are a bit meh and need working on from Apple's perspective, think app store for Mac lol.Music integration is standard Apple.Every other streaming service is on here too.Best thing about this is if you have a big library of films and a 4K TV, the upgrade to 4K on any films are free if you bought the HD version, a rare freebie given by Apple.

review_title: Either a must have or slightly disappointing...
review_text: I’m sure by now most people know that this is the latest version of Apple TV available, so I won’t use this review to go into specific details such as specification. I will however point out some information that I would have found useful if deciding whether to buy this or not…1. Whilst a previous Apple product I purchased on Amazon turned out to be a fake, I can attest that this is an official Apple TV. At the time of my purchase, this was cheaper than buying from Apple direct, but not by a huge amount - also, it's not packaged as well as if sent from Apple, thus mine arrived with a dented box.2. The picture quality is mostly great (as you would expect from 4K) however, I found that the quality from Netflix looked better via the app on my TV than it does via the Apple box (since investigation, I've learnt that I'm not the only one who has found this).3. You can upload your own videos to the internal hard-drive if you download the VLC app - there are plenty of websites that tell you how to do this. Apple have deliberately made this a painful process as they want you to buy their films from iTunes.4. Given that you can get Prime, Netflix, iPlayer etc. from most smart-tv’s these days, this might only be worth the purchase if you have (or plan to build) an extensive iTunes library.5. The remote is hit and miss… sometimes it is genius and sometimes it seems too over-sensitive.6. Voice-control is pretty accurate and seems to find what I ask to search for 99% of the time - in addition, it seems to search all the apps you have to give you a choice of where to buy/rent/watch the movie from.7. You can use your phone to manually search and/or enter a password which is simple but effective (I hate having to select a letter at a time from a TV digital Qwerty keyboard).I’m mostly happy - it is after all a very clever piece of technology. I should point out that I had a number of vouchers to use to reduce the price and I have quite a few iTunes movies - if either of these points hadn’t have been the case I would have been disappointed, as nearly all apps are available in modern TV’s / Games consoles and movies that aren't made by apple can be played from a USB stick.

review_text: Works well as central place to access all catchup and streaming apps such as Amazon, Netflix and Youtube. Also one of the few ways of watching the new Britbox on a TV rather than ipad/phone/PC. Interface familiar to anyone with a smart phone - especially those familiar with IOS.Apple TV has very limited free content, but the Morning Show much better than expected from the reviews.Works really well in conjunction with apple music (subscription required) with many songs available with lyrics that scroll as the song plays - great for Karaoke. Can also access a massive choice of music videos. Also easy to link with your own itunes library on a PC on the same network. However the software needs improving. Should be able to group albums together for easy viewing but only way is to generate a massive playlist of individual tracks.The worst thing is the remote. Its too sensitive - even with practice. Voice controlled search is pretty good most of the time in recognising your voice accurately. Within the music app once you select search, you then have to scroll down to use voice activation, often going past the correct point due to the already mentioned oversensitive touch pad. The remote itself is not very nice or ergonomic to hold. Too minimalist and too small. Just discovered the lower half of the remote face is made of glass - which has now fractured after drop on hard floor. This has happened within a month of ownership, all other remotes are undamaged despite years (in some cases) of use. - not impressed. Have now ordered a protective cover - for which there is a massive choice on Amazon - I wonder why!Picture quality is very good. Screen savers have a lot of interesting content but you dont seem to be able to just select the ones you like best.Sound is also very good when played through hifi system, especially the music.To summarise, great access point to multiple TV apps and music, either your own or by subscription, Remote needs improving and control software not up to apples usual standard.Definately worth getting but looses 2 stars due to poor remote and poor Apple TV free content.

review_title: Easy setup but practically no content.
review_text: Like all Apple products this is a thing of beauty and you won't mind it showing on your desktop or next to your TV. Setup was a complete joy and silky smooth experience. If you already have apple iPhones or iPads then it's guaranteed but if you haven't your experience may be only slightly less pleasurable. It is slick and quick.Picture quality on a 4K display is excellent, especially if you have the right cable and display to view full 4K @60Hz. The remote control is super intuitive once you realise which half of it you should be sliding your fingers and thumbs on. The on-screen display gets some getting used to but if you know how to go back via the remote you can explore all the options in half an hour or less. All the free content is via free downloadable apps like iPlayer and ITV Play etc.When I bought this I got an offer of a one year subscription to Apple TV+ thrown in for free. Therein lies a problem with the Apple TV. When you first fire it up you think the lack of included content other than the BBC iPlayer etc is because you don't have subscription to Apple TV+ and then you get a subscription you realise there isn't much content on there either and what is there may be big budget, like 'See', but there isn't much 'must view'. Anything else like the latest films you need to pay extra for. If you already have an Amazon Fire 4K TV stick (which is considerably cheaper) and a fast wi-fi network, then there isn't much to be gained from buying an Apple TV.So overall a well designed device that feels good and looks good but doesn't really deliver the goods when it comes to content yet. I use the word 'yet' more in hope than expectation.Update - The remote control continues to be more annoying than Piers Morgan (UK Viewers) and less responsive to my needs. Buy an Amazon FireTV 4K instead for less than half the price and you can watch the apple stuff, which still isn't much, through that instead.

review_title: Overpriced but by far the best streaming system
review_text: I’ve used a range of TV streaming options and this is the best. It’s by far the most expensive too, and it’s hard to say if it’s worth paying nearly 10 times more than a Fire Stick for basically the same thing. You do need an Apple ID to sign in to this.But it just works, like most Apple things. Everything is effortless, your photos from iCloud are there. You can screen share from an iPad, iPhone or MacBook with the press of a button. It’s a joy to use, there are no annoying third party apps to download or sub menus to navigate. The user interface is intuitive and simple to use. The supplied remote is a little dinky but most connected TV remotes will operate it too.The Apple TV app includes programmes viewable on the Apple TV+ subscription, but also brings together programmes on all the apps, allowing for easy searching and picking up the last watched programme.Picture quality is superb, with Dolby Vision and Dobly Atmos built in, which gives super results on a compatible TV. There are all the apps I want in the Appstore. Games are also available, which aren’t my thing at all, but having tried them it doesn’t come close to a proper gaming system. It’s a little puzzling really as you’re paying for a higher end system, but it’s still no playstation in terms of processor power, so it falls in the middle. It’s really therefore more of a luxury streaming device with semi-impressive gaming potential.

review_title: Superseded by TV's better built-in app and features.
review_text: AppleTV has been around for a while now, and I've always been a big fan... until I went for a new 4K HDR TV (LG OLED CX55) and now suddenly it seems rather lacking.Here are the problems:The (still) dreadful text input mechanism that arranges the alphabet in one big line across the screen, so you have to move left/right to select letters. This makes entering usernames/passwords extremely cumbersome, and for passwords there's no option to show the password, so even more frustrating if you lose your place.It doesn't support 7.1 surround sound... only 5.1. In 2020 this is unforgivable. Even the Sony PS3 (released in 2006) supports 7.1!Movies under the Disney label are not available in 4K HDR / Dolby Vision from Apple's own store, but are via the Disney+ app.The LG TV (and probably your own brand of smart tv) already comes with superior versions of YouTube, Prime, Disney+, iPlayer and even AppleTV!The above apps properly support LG's remote control (the mouse pointer thing... which I love, and which mostly solves the text entry issue).The above apps have full support for proper 7.1 surround sound.And smart TVs these days have built-in support for screen casting too... and it seems to be more stable than the AppleTV version.It still doesn't support "Hey Siri" (because it has no built-in microphone)... you have to buy a HomePod for that.So really the only reason to buy an AppleTV Device in 2020 is if:* You don't have a smart TV* You want to stream items from your home iTunes library (via the very buggy "Computers: app)* You want to make Homekit work from outside your house and be able to use a small selection of the features.Very disappointing; I expect better from Apple.

review_title: Unreliable, awful interface, terrible remote control
review_text: I love Apple - I work on an iMac, I have an iPhone, iPod - still, yes! - and I love how everything about Apple products just works seamlessly. That is, with the exception of the ATV.Let's get the remote out of the way. Gorgeous to look at, appalling to use and live with. First up, it's glass, so you end up paranoid about dropping it or bumping it. Apple, in the wisdom, think that less is more - so it is minimalist to the point of being unusable. On/Off button? Nope. Shortcuts to any apps? Nope. And the touchscreen is so sensitive that even thinking about touching it sends you scrolling way past where you wanted to be, often in completely the wrong direction - it's awful.Then there's the user interface. It's cluttered, and confusing, and again, no simple way to just turn it off (go to settings, send it to sleep). It's a mess, and gets wearing trying to navigate to your favourite apps.The sound quality is great BUT the ATV does not like to be told that you don't want to output in Atmos. "But your amp supports it!" Yes, ATV, but I don't have an Atmos set up, so 5.1 please. "Are you sure? I can see Atmos, it's much better." Just 5.1, please. "Fine, I'll LIMIT you to 5.1 then, but I'll ask you to change to Atmos occasionally, and if you don't say no I'll just randomly output in Atmos."Now, this may have just been my bad luck with the reliability of a specific model, but that's all I can go on. In the 2 months I owned it I had to do 5 factory resets due to flashing light. Which then sets off the whole "no I don't want Siri, no, I don't want Atmos, yes I do want HDR 4.4.4", which gets tiresome after the second or third time.This thing costs £179. Now, I don't like comparing things at different price points, but the obvious one here is the Amazon Fire TV Cube, currently on sale at £59.99. It does 4K. It does HDR. It does Dolby Atmos, 7.1 surround. It has every app you can think of. And it is a third of the price. And it works, perfectly.Amazon were good enough to offer a refund on the woeful ATV as it was only just 2 months old, and beset with re-booting issues.

review_title: Care about picture quality? This is for you.
review_text: I bought this to see how it fared compared to my Amazon FireTV version 2 and NowTV smart box, having been fed up with the limitations of both in some respect or other.To cut to the chase: The Apple TV 4K does Amazon prime video content perfectly. MUCH better than the FireTV box. Amazon should be embarrassed that their own hardware is so badly shown up by a competitor's on **Amazon's own content**! The Amazon FireTV has been irritating me for years with its dropped frames, poor picture quality and inability to match frame rates. The Apple TV 4K blows it away in terms of picture quality and motion. This is probably due to the Apple's native frame rate matching that no other box appears to do (and this is the reason I decided to take a punt on one).On Netflix content: Picture quality is again far superior to the FireTV. Motion is perfect.On BBC iPlayer content: Good picture quality, but there's a MAJOR drawback. See below.Downsides I've found so far:* I HATE the Siri remote. What's wrong with buttons? Trying to fast forward or rewind with the track pad is always a frustrating experience and different technique from app to app. Minimalism gone mad. Oh yeah, it's slippery as an eel and completely the wrong size for my hand so it frequently goes flying across the room - and that's before I fling it from frustration! You can't tell which end is which in the dark. Hard to imagine why they would make such an un-ergonomic object. Good news is that the Apple TV can learn inputs from other remotes so you can use spare buttons from your TV remote for example. I will try to find an old Apple TV remote - one with buttons.* No subtitles possible on BBC iPlayer! What the? Come on BBC. Catch up.* NowTV content: This box is not going to replace my NowTV box. The NowTV app on the AppleTV is rubbish. No wish list is the biggest issue. Picture quality is good, though - as good as with the NowTV box. Frame rate matching doing its job with the 50Hz NowTV content. The NowTV box does iPlayer perfectly so I'll be using it for that.
